channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: E.U. Nears Ban on Russian Oil, as West’s Resolve Grows
item.description: An oil embargo, expected to be difficult and costly to Europe, was considered unlikely when the war began. But positions have hardened, and NATO countries are sending more weapons to Ukraine and more troops to its neighbors.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian workers swept away debris in front of an apartment building on Friday. The complex was hit by a Russian missile on Thursday evening.

item.title: In Ukraine, A Body Bag and a Sister in Denial
item.description: The war in Ukraine is so big that it has shaken the world. But for a sister looking for her missing older brother, it was reduced to a visit to a morgue.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: Oksana Pokhodenko after identifying the remains of her older brother Oleksandr Pokhodenko at a morgue this month in Zmiiv, Ukraine.

item.title: They Survived the Holocaust. Now, They Are Fleeing to Germany.
item.description: A complex operation is underway to evacuate Holocaust survivors from Ukraine. For rescuers and evacuees alike, it means confronting the past.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Galina Ploschenko, 88, in her room at a senior care center in Hanover, Germany.

item.title: On the Trail of Russian War Crimes
item.description: Lyudmyla Denisova, Ukraine’s top human rights official, is determined to right historical wrongs and make sure Russians are held to account.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lyudmyla Denisova, Ukraine’s human rights commissioner, has been working in overdrive since Russian troops invaded Ukraine in February.

item.title: During Ramadan, Palestinians Denied Access to Aqsa Mosque Turn to Smugglers
item.description: For Palestinian Muslims, praying at the Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem is an important part of Ramadan. Those barred by Israel are finding ways to get there anyway.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel’s separation barrier in the West Bank city of Bethlehem. Some Palestinians are finding ways around or over it.

item.title: Boris Becker Sentenced to Prison for Hiding Assets in Bankruptcy
item.description: The former tennis champion was found guilty by a London court on charges related to his 2017 insolvency.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Boris Becker and Lilian de Carvalho Monteiro, his partner, arriving at court in London on Friday. The sentence punctuated a startling fall from grace for the former tennis star.

item.title: Ramadan Nights Provide Cherished Pause in Tense Sudan
item.description: “We come here to forget it all,” one young musician said during the daily end of the fast. “The heat, the electricity cuts, the protests. Here, at least, we can sing.”
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdulmonam Eassa
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Abdulmonam Eassa for The New York Times

item.title: Millions of South Koreans Could Soon Get Younger (on Paper)
item.description: South Korea has three ways of calculating age, often adding a year or two to the international standard. The incoming president wants to change that.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Under one Korean method of calculating age, babies are considered to be a year old at birth.

item.title: In Echo of Soviet Era, Russia’s Movie Theaters Turn to Pirate Screenings
item.description: In a Cold War throwback, some venues are showing bootleg versions after Hollywood studios pulled films from the country. Still, viewer numbers have tanked.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: The Oktyabr movie theater in Moscow. Ticket sales to see films in Russia were reported to have fallen by about half in March, compared with the same period last year.

item.title: Ireland’s Census Collects Time Capsules to Be Opened in 100 Years
item.description: The makers of the survey included a space for people to write or draw a message. The contents of these so-called time capsules will be revealed in 100 years.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:description: The coast in Dublin last year.

item.title: In El Salvador, the President Cracks Down on Civil Liberties
item.description: Much of the country’s population is willing to tolerate an autocratic leader, if it means that someone will finally solve their most pressing problem: gang violence.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Daniele Volpe
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Salvadoran soldiers searching men for gang tattoos this month in Tonacatepeque.

item.title: A Woman’s Disappearance Sparks Outrage in Mexico Over Gender Violence
item.description: The case of Debanhi Escobar, 18, in Monterrey has ignited a national outcry over the government’s failure to deliver justice for missing women.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez and Alejandro Cegarra
item.media:description: Women protesting in Monterrey, Mexico, after the death of Debanhi Escobar, who went missing on April 9, during a wave of disappearances of women in Nuevo León state.

item.title: Started Out as a Fish. How Did It End Up Like This?
item.description: A meme about the transitional fossil Tiktaalik argues that although we did emerge from the sea, we aren’t doing just fine.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:description: Tiktaalik roseae, the extinct limbed fish that flopped its way onto land one day 375 million years ago. We’ve been flopping ever since.

item.title: Leader of E.U. Border Agency Departs After Accusations of Abuses During His Tenure
item.description: The head of the agency, which became emblematic of the bloc’s hardening migration policy, has faced mounting allegations of mismanagement, harassment and human rights abuses at Europe’s borders.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Fabrice Leggeri, the head of the European Border Agency, last year in Warsaw, Poland.

item.title: Beijing Closes Schools as It Tries to Contain an Outbreak
item.description: The city is heading into a long holiday weekend, and officials are discouraging travel and unnecessary gatherings.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Lining up for coronavirus testing in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: In Ukraine War, a Long Journey Begins in Prosecuting Rape
item.description: U.N. officials and human rights investigators are rushing more resources to authorities in Ukraine to help prosecute sex crimes.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Battle-damaged buildings in Kharkiv. In the first two weeks of April, about 400 cases of sexual violence by Russian soldiers were reported to Ukraine’s ombudswoman for human rights.

item.title: Anglo-Saxon Kings Made Sure to Eat Their Vegetables, Study Shows
item.description: Contrary to popular belief, the ruling classes gorged on meat only on rare occasions, according to an analysis of more than 2,000 skeletons buried during medieval times.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer

item.title: Vaccines for Young Children
item.description: The federal government is telling us two different stories.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A Moderna Covid-19 vaccine trial in Commack, N.Y., last year.

item.title: Solar Industry ‘Frozen’ as Biden Administration Investigates China
item.description: More than 300 solar projects in the United States have been canceled or delayed in recent weeks because of an investigation by the Commerce Department.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:description: A solar panel production line in Baoding, China. Tariffs on Chinese solar panels have been in place since 2012.

item.title: Ukraine Identifies Russian Soldiers in Bucha Atrocities
item.description: In the first detailed set of allegations since the invasion, Ukrainian officials published the names and photos of Russian soldiers they say tortured civilians in a suburb of Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A disabled tank in Bucha, a suburb of Kyiv, this month.

item.title: Weighing Risk When the Reporting Is Dangerous
item.description: A security team watches out for Times journalists abroad. There are strategies in place, but sometimes there’s no other choice but to leave a country.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers detained an antiwar protester in Moscow on Feb. 25. The Russian government outlawed independent information about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in early March.

item.title: 8,000 British Troops to Join Allied Exercises in Eastern Europe, Official Says
item.description: The troops will serve in the British-led Joint Expeditionary Force, created in 2014 in response to Russia’s seizure of Crimea from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: British Royal Marines with members of the Latvian National Guard during a Joint Expeditionary Force training exercise in Latvia in 2019.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: President Biden’s push for more aid to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden speaking at the White House yesterday about his request for aid to Ukraine.

item.title: Is Australian Democracy in Decline?
item.description: With a federal election just a few weeks away, it’s time to put Australia’s system and political flaws into context.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: Polling booths in a Melbourne suburb during the last federal election in 2019.

item.title: Russian Intelligence Behind Novaya Gazeta Editor Attack, U.S. Official Says
item.description: Dmitri Muratov was on a train preparing to leave Moscow at the time of the attack, which caused chemical burns to his eyes.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dmitri Muratov in the Novaya Gazeta offices in 2021.

item.title: BART Reinstates Its Mask Mandate
item.description: The decision will be effective until July 18, and could be extended.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:description: Commuters in the Embarcadero station in San Francisco on Thursday.

item.title: Biden Seeks $33 Billion More in Aid for Ukraine
item.description: “The cost of this fight is not cheap,” President Biden said. He also sent Congress a plan to increase the government’s power to seize luxury yachts, aircraft and other assets of Russian oligarchs.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: President Biden called on Congress to authorize $33 billion in aid to Ukraine, a dramatic escalation of American spending in the war.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: China’s Stimulus Plan
item.description: Plus a U.S. push for Ukraine funds and extreme heat in India and Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Workers at a construction site in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: States Sue Postal Service Over New Gas-Powered Mail Trucks
item.description: Sixteen states argue the Postal Service failed to properly vet clean alternatives to polluting trucks that could get as little as 8.6 miles to the gallon.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Postal Service owns more than 231,000 vehicles, one of the largest civilian fleets in the world.

item.title: Chernobyl Radiation Levels Within Safe Limits, Nuclear Agency Chief Says
item.description: The finding came after readings were taken this week at the site, which Russian forces had occupied but withdrew from in late March.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Chernobyl Reactor Number 4 site, now heavily sealed and protected, was the source of the nuclear disaster in 1986.

item.title: In Warming World Oceans Risk Mass Extinctions, Model Shows
item.description: A new study finds that if fossil fuel emissions continue apace, the oceans could experience a mass extinction by 2300. There is still time to avoid it.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Chris & Monique Fallows/Nature Picture Library, via Alamy
item.media:description: Dolphins feeding off the east coast of South Africa.

item.title: Turkey’s Erdogan Heads to Saudi Arabia to Ease Tensions
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is visiting the kingdom for the first time in nearly five years, signaling a mending of relations over the killing of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in 2020. He said his Saudi trip was part of Turkey’s efforts to promote peace, dialogue and diplomacy in the region.

item.title: Are Traditional Political Parties Dead in France?
item.description: Presidents, prime ministers, Parliament — France’s mainstream left and right-wing parties used to have it all. In the first round of April’s presidential elections, they got less than 7 percent of the vote.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of France’s Socialist Party, in Blois, in August. Anne Hidalgo, the Socialist candidate, garnered just 1.75 percent of the vote in France’s presidential election.

item.title: Tensions Flare Between Neighbors After Afghan Man Kills Iranian Clerics
item.description: The attack led to ethnic tensions in both countries, which each sent troops to the border.
item.dc:creator: Sharif Hassan and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Mourners gathering around the flag-clad casket of Iranian Shiite Muslim cleric Mohammad Aslani at his funeral in the northeastern Iranian city of Mashhad, on April 7.

item.title: South Korea Arrests 2 Accused of Spying for North Korea
item.description: The men were paid in cryptocurrency by a man suspected of being a North Korean spy agent, the South Korean national police agency said.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun

item.title: Top U.N. Official Tours Kyiv, Declaring the War ‘An Absurdity’
item.description: António Guterres’ goals include securing evacuation routes for besieged civilians and supporting the prosecution of war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Maria Varenikova
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: António Guterres, the U.N. secretary general, on Thursday in a destroyed area of the city of Irpin, Ukraine.

item.title: At N.F.L. Draft, America Begins Annual Tradition of Celebrating Hubris
item.description: Tonight, America begins an annual festival celebrating hubris.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Sam Navarro/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Josh Allen of the Buffalo Bills last year.

item.title: India’s Extreme Heat Is Expected to Worsen
item.description: The Indian subcontinent has recorded above-average temperatures for weeks. Heat-related weather watches or alerts are now in effect for hundreds of millions of people.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Mike Ives

item.title: Deforestation Remains High, Despite COP 26 Pledges
item.description: Brazil had the largest share of tree loss last year, followed by the Democratic Republic of Congo and Bolivia. Indonesia showed improvement.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A forest fire burning in the Pantanal, Mato Grosso state, Brazil, last year.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A potential gas crisis in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A gas storage facility in Chiren, Bulgaria.

item.title: Fears Mount That Ukraine War Will Become a Broader Conflict
item.description: American and European officials say their concern is based in part on a growing conviction that the war will not end any time soon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Families arriving in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, last week after fleeing Mariupol, which is under siege by Russian forces.

item.title: Former U.S. Ambassador to Plead Guilty to Illegal Lobbying and Hiding Gifts
item.description: Richard Olson lobbied for the government of Qatar soon after retiring and took gifts from a businessman while serving as ambassador to Pakistan, according to prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Richard Olson worked as a Foreign Service officer for 34 years.

item.title: Colombian General and 10 Others Admit to Crimes Against Humanity
item.description: In the first hearing of its kind, officials admitted to orchestrating extrajudicial killings. But victims asked for more. “We know that there are powerful people behind you,” said one woman. “We need names.”
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Sofía Villamil
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Néstor Guillermo Gutiérrez, a former corporal in the Colombian military, spoke about killing civilians during that country’s civil war during a hearing on Tuesday in Ocaña, Colombia, organized by a special court.

item.title: Ukraine War Impact Widens: Russia Cuts Gas Flow and Vows More Reprisals
item.description: New explosions across Ukraine’s borders, Russia’s shut-off of natural gas to two European nations and Moscow’s warning of additional “counterstrikes” pointed to escalating hostilities.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Neil MacFarquhar, Shashank Bengali and Megan Specia
item.media:description: A gas processing station in Chiren, Bulgaria. Russia’s state-run gas company, Gazprom, announced that it was suspending natural gas shipments to Poland and Bulgaria on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Cuts Gas Supplies
item.description: Also, Shanghai residents express anger and Singapore executes an intellectually disabled man.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Gazprom said it paused shipments after the two companies refused to pay in rubles, but the move follows news of the West’s escalating arms shipments to Ukraine.

item.title: The Largest U.S. Coronavirus Hot Spot Swells Beyond Central New York
item.description: Health experts say that people in the hot spot, which includes cities like Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse, should be increasing their precautions.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan and Lauren McCarthy
item.media:credit: Heather Ainsworth for The New York Times
item.media:description: After lifting earlier Covid-19 measures, Syracuse University in Onondaga County, N.Y., has reinstated an indoor mask mandate because of a case surge.

item.title: Britain Broke the Law by Moving Hospital Patients to Nursing Homes Early in Pandemic, Court Rules
item.description: The court’s ruling came in a lawsuit brought by two women whose fathers died in nursing homes in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: The Covid Memorial Wall in London. About 20,000 nursing home residents in England and Wales died from Covid-related causes between March and June 2020, according to government figures.

item.title: Italian Children to Be Given Mother’s and Father’s Surnames, Court Rules
item.description: The ruling overturns decades of patriarchal family legacy, which largely left women out of the decision-making process.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A baptism in Catania, Italy, last year. A statement from Italy’s Constitutional Court cited principles of equality and children’s interest in explaining its decision.

item.title: Russia Uses Cyberattacks in Ukraine to Support Military Strikes, Report Finds
item.description: A new study by Microsoft shows that Russian cyberattacks often happened within days or even hours of missile strikes.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and David E. Sanger

item.title: Questions Over Death of Ayman Hadhoud, an Egyptian Economist
item.description: Ayman Hadhoud, a well-known liberal economist and critic of the government, was researching corruption before he disappeared under mysterious circumstances.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and David D. Kirkpatrick
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Egyptian police special forces in Cairo in 2016. The country’s police and security agencies have a long record of detaining, abusing and torturing citizens, especially those considered political opponents.

item.title: The Unsettling Warning in France’s Election
item.description: A record number of abstentions, and a strictly binary choice for voters — many of whom said they were picking the lesser of two evils — are trouble signs even within a mature democracy.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Emmanuel Macron reacting to the announcement of his victory in the second round of France’s presidential election, on April 24.

item.title: Ukrainians Flood Village of Demydiv to Keep Russians at Bay
item.description: The waters that poured into Demydiv were one of many instances of Ukraine wreaking havoc on its own territory to slow Russia’s advance. Residents couldn’t be happier. “We saved Kyiv,” one said.
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: 20 Percent of Reptiles Risk Extinction, From King Cobras to Geckos
item.description: The first global analysis of its kind found that logging and farming are taking away reptile habitat at an unsustainable pace, exacerbating a worldwide decline in biodiversity.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature
item.media:description: The forest-dwelling lesser chameleon of Madagascar is threatened by mining and logging.

item.title: E.U. Says the Emergency Phase of the Pandemic Is Over
item.description: The bloc recommended focusing on vaccination, surveillance and testing in preparation for a possible fall wave. E.U. states can still make their own policies.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission’s president, said on Wednesday that it was crucial to stay vigilant against Covid.
